questiontext.text:
Exercise

The function \(f = x^2 + y^2\) is to be integrated over an elliptical cone with base being the ellipse, \(x^2/4 + y^2 = 1\), \(z=0\) and apex (point) at \((0,0,{@yu@})\). The integral can be made simpler by means of the change of variables \[x = {@aa@}\left(1-\dfrac{w}{5}\right) \tau \cos \theta, \qquad y = \left(1-\dfrac{w}{5}\right) \tau \sin \theta, \qquad z=w.\] [[jsxgraph]] const board = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard('jxgbox', { boundingbox: [-4, 4, 4, -1], axis: false, showNavigation: false }); // Axes points const Xr = board.create('point', [3, 0], {visible: false, fixed: true}); const Xl = board.create('point', [-3, 0], {visible: false, fixed: true}); const Yl = board.create('point', [0, 3.5], {visible: false, fixed: true}); const Yu = board.create('point', [0, -1], {visible: false, fixed: true}); const Zl = board.create('point', [3, 2], {visible: false, fixed: true}); const Zu = board.create('point', [-0.75, -0.5], {visible: false, fixed: true}); // Back triangle const O = board.create('point', [0, 0], {visible: false, fixed: true}); const Ae = board.create('point', [1.6, 0], {visible: false, fixed: true}); const Be = board.create('point', [-1.6, 0], {visible: false, fixed: true}); const A = board.create('point', [1.65, 0], {visible: false, fixed: true}); const B = board.create('point', [-1.65, 0], {visible: false, fixed: true}); const C = board.create('point', [0, -0.4], {visible: false, fixed: true}); const P = board.create('point', [0, 3], {visible: false, fixed: true}); // Front triangle const D = board.create('point', [-2, 0], {visible: false, fixed: true}); const E = board.create('point', [-2, -2], {visible: false, fixed: true}); const F = board.create('point', [-0.5, -2], {visible: false, fixed: true}); // Axes with labels board.create('arrow', [Xl, Xr], {strokeColor: 'black', name: 'X', withLabel: false,fontSize: 12}); board.create('arrow', [Yu, Yl], {strokeColor: 'black', name: 'Y', withLabel: false,fontSize: 12}); board.create('arrow', [Zu, Zl], {strokeColor: 'black', name: 'Z', withLabel: false,fontSize: 12}); board.create('line', [A, P], {straightFirst: false, straightLast: false}); board.create('line', [B, P], {straightFirst: false, straightLast: false}); var el = board.create('ellipse',[Ae,Be,C],{strokeWidth: 2}); // Add other labels board.create('text', [0.1, 3.1, '\\((0,0,{#yu#})\\)'], {fontSize: 12,fixed: true}); board.create('text', [1.7, -0.1, '\\((2,0,0)\\)'], {fontSize: 12,fixed: true}); board.create('text', [-2.6, -0.1, '\\((-2,0,0)\\)'], {fontSize: 12,fixed: true}); board.create('text', [0.1, -0.5, '\\((0,-1,0)\\)'], {fontSize: 12,fixed: true}); [[/jsxgraph]]

  1. Find the limits on the variables \(\tau\), \(\theta\) and \(w\).
    \(\tau: \) [[input:ans1al]] to [[input:ans1au]]. [[validation:ans1al]] [[validation:ans1au]] [[feedback:prt1a]]
    \(\theta: \) [[input:ans1bl]] to [[input:ans1bu]]. [[validation:ans1bl]] [[validation:ans1bu]][[feedback:prt1b]]
    \(w: \) [[input:ans1cl]] to [[input:ans1cu]]. [[validation:ans1cl]] [[validation:ans1cu]][[feedback:prt1c]]
  2. Find the Jacobian \(J(\tau,\theta,w)\) for this transformation. Input \(\tau\) as tau
    \(|J|=\,\)[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]
  3. Express the integral \(\displaystyle\int\!\!\int\!\!\int (x^2 + y^2)\;\mathrm{d}x \,\mathrm{d}y \,\mathrm{d}z\) in terms of \(\tau\), \(\theta\) and \(w\). Then evaluate this integral. [Hint:- it may be worth noting that \(\cos^2 \theta \equiv\frac{1}{2}(1+ \cos 2\theta)\)]. Note: This integral has relevance in topics such as moments of inertia.
    \(I=\;\)[[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]][[feedback:prt4]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. \(\tau : 0\) to \(1 \, \, \), \(\theta : 0\) to \(2\pi\). These are the bounds of the trigonometric values.

    \(w : 0\) to \({@yu@}\). This is the bounds of the z axis.

  2. Evaluating the partial derivatives,
    \[\dfrac{\partial x}{\partial \tau}= {@dxdt@},\] \[\quad \dfrac{\partial x}{\partial \theta}= {@dxdu@},\] \[\quad \dfrac{\partial x}{\partial w}= {@dxdw@},\]
    \[ \dfrac{\partial y}{\partial \tau}= {@dydt@},\] \[\dfrac{\partial y}{\partial \theta}= {@dydu@},\] \[\dfrac{\partial y}{\partial w}= {@dydw@},\]
    \[\dfrac{\partial z}{\partial \tau}= {@dzdt@},\] \[ \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial \theta}= {@dzdu@},\] \[ \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial w}= {@dzdw@}\]
    so the Jacobian is \[\left| \begin{array}{ccc} \dfrac{\partial x}{\partial \tau} & \dfrac{\partial x}{\partial \theta} & \dfrac{\partial x}{\partial w} \\ \\ \dfrac{\partial y}{\partial \tau} & \dfrac{\partial y}{\partial \theta} & \dfrac{\partial y}{\partial w} \\ \\ \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial \tau} & \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial \theta} & \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial w} \end{array} \right| = \left| \begin{array}{ccc} {@dxdt@} & {@dxdu@} & {@dxdw@} \\ \\ {@dydt@} & {@dydu@} & {@dydw@} \\ \\ {@dzdt@} & {@dzdu@} & {@dzdw@} \end{array}\right| = {@ta2@} \] where expansion of the determinant has taken place down the first column.
  3. \begin{align} I &= \int\int\int(x^2+y^2) \; \mathrm{d}x\, \mathrm{d}y\, \mathrm{d}z\\ &=\int\int\int(x^2+y^2)J(\tau,\omega,w)\; \mathrm{d}w\, \mathrm{d}\theta\, \mathrm{d}\tau\\ &=\int\int\int\left(\left({@f1@}\right)^2+\left({@f2@}\right)^2\right){@ta2@}\; \mathrm{d}w\, \mathrm{d}\theta\, \mathrm{d}\tau\\ &={@aa@} \displaystyle\int_{\tau=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{\theta=0}^{2\pi} \displaystyle\int_{w=0}^{@yu@} (1-\frac{w}{5})^4 \tau^3 (4 \cos^2 \theta + \sin^2 \theta )\; \mathrm{d}w\, \mathrm{d}\theta\, \mathrm{d}\tau\\ &=\int_{\tau=0}^1\displaystyle\int_{\theta=0}^{2\pi} \displaystyle \displaystyle\Bigg[{@fbI11@}\Bigg]_{w=0}^{@yu@}\;\mathrm{d}\theta\,\mathrm{d}\tau\\ &= \int_{\tau=0}^1\displaystyle\int_{\theta=0}^{2\pi}{@I11@}\;\mathrm{d}\theta\,\mathrm{d}\tau\\ &= \int_{\tau=0}^1 \Bigg[{@fbI12@}\Bigg]_{\theta=0}^{2\pi}\;\mathrm{d}\tau\\ &=\displaystyle\int_{\tau=0}^1 {@I12@}\;\mathrm{d}\tau\\ &= \Bigg[{@fbI13@}\Bigg]_{\tau=0}^1= {@ta4@} \end{align}
